pullRequest.body:
This defines the *adjoint action* of a Lie algebra `L` on itself, when seen as an homomorphism of Lie algebras from `L` to the Lie algebra of its derivations. 

The adjoint action was also defined in the `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.OfAssociative.lean` file, under the name `LieAlgebra.ad`, as the homomorphism with values in the endormophisms of `L`. We make the link between both. This design choice was discussed in [this thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Derivations.20on.20Lie.20algebras).

We also establish elementary properties, such as the fact that the image of the adjoint action is an ideal of the derivations.

This is the penultimate step towards proving that all derivations of a finite-dimensional semisimple Lie algebra are inner, a goal described in [this thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Derivations.20on.20Lie.20algebras).

nodes.body: :v: frederic-marbach can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8690066766/job/23829105535)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8690066766/job/23829104167)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8690066766/job/23829105178)
It's great to see this theory coming to life! I have a couple of suggestions around definitions. I'll review again once you've had a chance to respond.

Thanks!

Just two tiny last suggestions.

bors d+
I think this `Inner` section should be moved to the `Lie.Derivation.Basic` file.

If you add the following missing instance to the file `Lie.Derivation.Basic`:
```lean
instance : SMulBracketCommClass R L M := ⟨fun t x m ↦ (lie_smul t x m).symm⟩
```
then you can make a slightly stronger definition here:
```suggestion
/-- The natural map from a Lie module to the derivations taking values in it. -/
@[simps!]
def inner : M →ₗ[R] LieDerivation R L M where
  toFun m :=
    { __ := (LieModule.toEndomorphism R L M : L →ₗ[R] Module.End R M).flip m
      leibniz' := by simp }
  map_add' m n := by ext; simp
  map_smul' t m := by ext; simp
```
We had `instance : SMulBracketCommClass R L L`, which I replaced with your more general version instead.

If you promote `inner` to a linear map as suggested above, then this can become:
```suggestion
/-- The adjoint action of a Lie algebra `L` on itself, seen as a morphism of Lie algebras from
`L` to its derivations.

Note the minus sign: this is chosen to so that there is no minus sign in `LieDerivation.ad_eq_ad`. -/
def ad : L →ₗ⁅R⁆ LieDerivation R L L :=
  { __ := - inner R L L
    map_lie' := by
      intro x y
      ext z
      simp only [AddHom.toFun_eq_coe, LinearMap.coe_toAddHom, LinearMap.neg_apply, coe_neg,
        Pi.neg_apply, inner_apply_apply, commutator_apply]
      rw [leibniz_lie, neg_lie, neg_lie, ← lie_skew x]
      abel }
```
You could even place the minus sign outside the entire structure (i.e. `def ad : L →ₗ⁅R⁆ LieDerivation R L L := -{ ...}`) as this might make the proof of `map_lie'` easier.
I don't think I can place the minus sign outside, since then it looks like I have `ad [x,y] = - [ad(x), ad(y)]`? In fact I added the minus sign in the first place to have a morphism of Lie algebras.

Oh right, thanks; good point!

This makes me vaguely wonder if we should redefine `inner` to be what is currently `- inner`. Anyway, what you have is best for now I think.

I slightly prefer:
```suggestion
Note the minus sign: this is chosen to so that `ad ⁅x, y⁆ = ⁅ad x, ad y⁆`. -/
```
(even though I realise the actual Lean would be `ad R L` rather than `ad`)

You can use `simps!` here:
```suggestion
@[simps!] def ad : L →ₗ⁅R⁆ LieDerivation R L L :=
```
It will generate a lemma called `ad_apply_apply` which is exactly your `ad_apply` below.
(Btw if you write `@[simps!?]` and mouseover in VSCode, you can see what lemmas `@[simps!]` is creating.)

We don't need `ad_zero` and `ad_lie` because these are true simply because of the type of `ad`. And we don't need `ad_apply` if you add `simps!` above as suggested.
```suggestion

lemma ad_zero : ad R L 0 = 0 := LieHom.map_zero (ad R L)

@[simp]
lemma ad_apply (x y : L) : ad R L x y = ⁅x, y⁆ := by
  rw [ad, LieHom.coe_mk, AddHom.toFun_eq_coe, LinearMap.coe_toAddHom, LinearMap.neg_apply, coe_neg,
    Pi.neg_apply, inner_apply_apply, lie_skew]

lemma ad_lie (x y z : L) : ad R L x ⁅y, z⁆ = ⁅y, ad R L x z⁆ + ⁅ad R L x y, z⁆ := by
  rw [apply_lie_eq_add]
```

```suggestion
/-- The definitions `LieDerivation.ad` and `LieAlgebra.ad` agree. -/
@[simp] lemma coe_ad_apply_eq_ad_apply (x : L) : ad R L x = LieAlgebra.ad R L x := by ext; simp
```

Given that we have [LieAlgebra.self_module_ker_eq_center](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Abelian.html#LieAlgebra.self_module_ker_eq_center) I don't think we need this lemma; we can rely on just `ad_ker_eq_center` below.
```suggestion
```

If we drop `ad_ker_eq_self_module_ker` above then this proof can be something like:
```suggestion
  rw [← LieAlgebra.self_module_ker_eq_center, LieHom.mem_ker, LieModule.mem_ker]
  simp [DFunLike.ext_iff]
```

```suggestion
/-- The commutator of a derivation `D` and a derivation of the form `ad x` is `ad (D x)`. -/
```

Firstly a minor point of Mathlib terminology: we use `image` for the image of a subset and `range` for the image of all of the domain. So you really want the word "range" instead of "image" here.

Secondly IIUC, what you have defined is exactly `(ad R L).idealRange`. So I think you can drop this definition and instead prove the lemma:
```lean
lemma coe_ad_idealRange :
    ((ad R L).idealRange : Submodule R _) = LinearMap.range (ad R L).toLinearMap := by
  sorry
```
from which (a renamed version of) `mem_imageAd_iff` should follow easily.

The API around `LieHom.idealRange` is not in great shape (I defined this a very long time ago when we were all, and especially I, were still learning what was best) but hopefully not too bad.
Thanks. In fact, you had even better: `LieHom.IsIdealMorphism`, which seems to be exactly the property we are proving here. I also changed an "image" to a "range" in a comment there.
Great point! This is indeed a job for `LieHom.IsIdealMorphism` :-)

Even though I have proposed dropping this definition, I note in passing that these fields are redundant because they are included in the spread `__ := ` above.
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
lemma ad_isIdealMorphism : (ad R L).IsIdealMorphism := by
```

I think we should drop this lemma as it is just a special case of `LieHom.mem_idealRange`. 
```suggestion
```
For emphasis:
```lean
example (x : L) : ad R L x ∈ (ad R L).idealRange := (ad R L).mem_idealRange
```
Though writing that I see that `x` in `LieHom.mem_idealRange` is implicit and should probably be explicit: feel free to make this change to `LieHom.mem_idealRange`!
I did the change and adapted the only place it was used before.

Come to think of it, we also don't need this lemma:
```suggestion
```
(again because you proved `LieDerivation.ad_isIdealMorphism`)

This a great opportunity for me to ask the following question. 
1. In the first case, I understand that my `ad_mem_rangeAd ` was just a particular case of `LieHom.mem_idealRange`, so I fully get (and agree with) why we prefer to keep only the general one. 
2. Now here `mem_rangeAd_iff` is a combination of two lemmas `LieHom.mem_idealRange_iff` and `ad_isIdealMorphism`. Sure it's very easy to combine both, but it still makes it a little bit harder to find the correct combination then having it already packaged no? Where does the mathlib community draw the line? Combination of 3 lemmas?

*For the moment, I only removed `ad_mem_rangeAd`. But I will happily remove this too after I understand!*
(discussed elsewhere)
